meta.name: Curriculum-Making Alignment Framework (Conceptual x Actor)
notes: Designed for an interactive web explainer + teacher-facing diagnostic tools.
All categories are ideal-types; real settings often hybridize under constraints.

scale.label: Naive Realism
scale.definition: Reality can be understood through appropriate methods.

scale.label: Structural Realism
scale.definition: Theories describe aspects/structures of reality; underlying essence may remain uncertain.

scale.label: Critical Realism
scale.definition: Reality exists and can be approached through critical examination of deeper mechanisms.

scale.label: Bounded Relativism
scale.definition: Psychological constructions of reality are valid within cultural/moral/cognitive boundaries.

scale.label: Relativism
scale.definition: Reality is multiple and constructed; no mind-independent reality is accessible/meaningful.

scale.label: Objectivism
scale.definition: Meaning is in the object, independent of the knower.

scale.label: Constructionism
scale.definition: Meaning emerges from subject–object interaction; the knower constructs meaning.

scale.label: Subjectivism
scale.definition: Meaning is in the subject; the knower assigns meaning.

levels.name: Educational Philosophy
levels.guiding_question: Why educate? What kind of person/society is education for? (aims/ends)

levels.name: Curriculum Conception (Curriculum Orientation)
levels.guiding_question: What is curriculum, primarily for, in institutional schooling?

levels.name: Curriculum Design Type (Organizational Form)
levels.guiding_question: How is content/experience organized across time and subjects? (scope/sequence/integration)

mechanism_summary: Philosophy supplies value/legitimacy for aims and a worldview about knowledge and persons.
Curriculum conception translates those assumptions into a dominant 'function of curriculum' language for institutions.
Design type operationalizes that function into structures (scope/sequence/integration) and default evidence systems.
In practice, feedback loops occur: implementation evidence and constraints can reshape conceptions and even aims.

axis_B_curriculum_making.premise: Curriculum is dynamically made through interaction among actors across system levels; agency is ecological (enabled/constrained by structural, cultural, and material conditions).

sites_of_activity.description: Transnational/global discourse, benchmarks, and policy borrowing; professional networks; research and thought-leadership.
National/state/provincial curriculum policy, standards, qualifications, accountability regimes.
District/local authority and school-level translation: leadership, timetables, resourcing, professional learning, local priorities.
Classroom enactment: teachers and students interpret, adapt, and negotiate curriculum-in-use.
Moment-to-moment interaction and learner experience: participation, identity, meaning-making, assessment talk.

educational_philosophies.label: Perennialism
aims: initiate learners into enduring ideas and classic disciplines

educational_philosophies.label: Essentialism
aims: master core skills and foundational disciplines

curriculum_conceptions.label: Academic Rationalism
curriculum_conceptions.definition: Curriculum as disciplined knowledge and cultural inheritance organized by canonical subjects and their structures.
curriculum_conceptions.primary_function: Transmit and induct learners into accumulated disciplinary knowledge and intellectual traditions.

curriculum_conceptions.label: Cognitive Processes
curriculum_conceptions.definition: Curriculum as a vehicle for developing transferable thinking processes (reasoning, problem-solving, metacognition).
curriculum_conceptions.primary_function: Develop general cognitive skills; content serves as the medium for cognitive growth.
content_principle: high-leverage tasks that elicit target thinking
cognitive demand and opportunities for transfer

curriculum_conceptions.label: Curriculum as Technology
curriculum_conceptions.definition: Curriculum as a technical system to efficiently achieve pre-specified objectives; focuses on 'how' to deliver outcomes.
curriculum_conceptions.primary_function: Efficiency and efficacy in achieving measurable goals; standardization and replicability.
content_principle: content-neutral or interchangeable; selected for alignment to objectives and assessability

curriculum_conceptions.label: Self-Actualization / Consummatory Experience
curriculum_conceptions.definition: Curriculum as meaningful lived experience that supports identity, autonomy, and holistic personal growth.
curriculum_conceptions.primary_function: Support learners' self-understanding and full development; curriculum as an enabling process.
pedagogy_bias: supportive climate; confluence of affect and cognition

curriculum_conceptions.label: Social Reconstruction / Relevance
curriculum_conceptions.definition: Curriculum as a socially situated program for interpreting and transforming society; foregrounds justice, relevance, and the future.
curriculum_conceptions.primary_function: Build civic competence and agency; critique inequity and support collective improvement.

curriculum_design_types.label: Subject-Centered Design
curriculum_design_types.definition: Curriculum organized around subject/discipline knowledge structures and sequences.

subtypes.label: Subject Design
planning_practices: build scope-and-sequence by grade/course; prioritize coverage and prerequisites
map standards to units; pacing guides; common assessments calendar
instruction_practices: explicit teaching + modeling; worked examples; guided practice; retrieval practice
textbook/primary sources; structured discussions; lab demos as confirmation
assessment_practices: unit tests/quizzes (criterion-referenced); essays/short answers aligned to content
common item analysis and reteach cycles
tradeoffs: may privilege students with prior cultural capital

example_cards.planning: sequence from integers → expressions → equations; daily learning targets
example_cards.instruction: I do / We do / You do; error analysis routines
example_cards.assessment: weekly quiz + cumulative test; mastery-based retakes

example_cards.planning: chronological unit map; key concepts + vocabulary list
genre units; reading list; explicit skills progression
example_cards.instruction: close reading protocol; sentence-combining drills; Socratic seminar

subtypes.label: Discipline Design
planning_practices: organize units around 'big ideas' and disciplinary practices (e.g., modeling, argumentation)
spiral key concepts; plan inquiry sequences with disciplinary tools
instruction_practices: disciplinary apprenticeship: modeling how experts think; inquiry with explicit method teaching
argument from evidence; critique and revision cycles
assessment_practices: performance tasks requiring disciplinary methods (investigations, proofs, critiques)
rubrics for practices (evidence use, modeling, reasoning)

example_cards.planning: big idea map + misconceptions; design investigation + argument task
conceptual model progression; plan labs that reveal invariants

subtypes.label: Broad-Fields Design
planning_practices: merge related subjects into fields (e.g., social studies); establish shared big questions
develop interdisciplinary progressions and common vocabulary
instruction_practices: thematic units; cross-disciplinary texts and tools; integration mini-lessons
structured projects but anchored to field outcomes
assessment_practices: integrated performance tasks; field-based exams (concepts across sub-disciplines)
projects evaluated with multi-criteria rubrics

example_cards.planning: geography + history + civics outcomes; timeline + map skills
energy as unifying concept; cross-unit phenomena

subtypes.label: Correlation Design
planning_practices: maintain separate subjects but coordinate timing and shared themes
create cross-curricular planning checkpoints
instruction_practices: teachers reference parallel learning (e.g., stats in science)
shared projects used as integration moments
assessment_practices: parallel rubrics for shared skills (argument, data literacy)
capstone tasks that pull from multiple subjects
best_fit_for: schools keeping subject timetables but wanting coherence

example_cards.planning: align WWII unit with novel study

subtypes.label: Process Design
planning_practices: define target thinking processes (scientific method, critical thinking) and embed across subjects
select tasks for cognitive demand; plan metacognitive routines
instruction_practices: explicit strategy instruction; modeling thinking; gradual release
thinking routines (e.g., claim-support-question) across lessons
assessment_practices: process rubrics; reflection prompts; transfer tasks in new contexts
portfolio of thinking artifacts (notes, drafts, revisions)

example_cards.planning: common process rubric; benchmark tasks each term

curriculum_design_types.label: Learner-Centered Design
curriculum_design_types.definition: Curriculum organized around learners' needs, interests, developmental tasks, and lived experience.

subtypes.label: Child-Centered Design
planning_practices: start from learners' questions; co-plan inquiries; flexible pacing
diagnose readiness and interests; differentiate pathways
instruction_practices: workshops, centers, exploration; teacher as facilitator
student choice in tasks and products; formative conferencing
assessment_practices: observational records; formative check-ins; student self-assessment
portfolio of artifacts demonstrating growth

subtypes.label: Experience-Centered (Activity) Design
planning_practices: design rich experiences (fieldwork, making, simulations) that generate questions
plan reflection cycles to turn experience into learning
instruction_practices: experiential tasks; debrief protocols; iterative making
community resources and authentic audiences
assessment_practices: performance + reflection; peer feedback; narrative assessment
rubrics for process (planning, iteration, reflection)

subtypes.label: Humanistic Design
planning_practices: plan for belonging, identity, and emotional safety as explicit design goals
integrate value clarification and self-reflection opportunities
instruction_practices: dialogic circles; journaling; choice-based reading/writing
teacher stance: empathy, authenticity, respect; co-created norms
assessment_practices: student-led conferences; reflective portfolios
qualitative indicators (agency, self-regulation, meaning-making)
tradeoffs: risk of being seen as 'soft' if outcomes unclear

subtypes.label: Radical / Reform Design
planning_practices: co-determine aims with learners; critical examination of schooling itself
plan for voice, dissent, and negotiated curriculum
instruction_practices: problem-posing dialogue; student-led investigations; self-directed learning contracts
peer teaching and democratic governance routines
assessment_practices: negotiated criteria; public exhibitions; reflective critique
evidence includes participation in collective decisions and action
tradeoffs: difficult to align to mandated standards

example_cards.context: Youth inquiry on school discipline policy

curriculum_design_types.label: Problem-Centered Design
curriculum_design_types.definition: Curriculum organized around real-world problems, themes, or social issues to support application and civic competence.

subtypes.label: Life-Situations (Life-Centered/Core) Design
planning_practices: select life roles/situations (health, finance, citizenship) as organizers
map required knowledge/skills from multiple subjects into themes
instruction_practices: case-based learning; simulations; applied projects
explicit teaching of needed concepts as they arise
assessment_practices: authentic products (budgets, plans, presentations)
scenario-based assessments

subtypes.label: Reconstructionist (Critical/Action) Design
planning_practices: choose public issues with local relevance; map stakeholders and risks
plan inquiry → deliberation → action → reflection cycle
instruction_practices: critical media literacy; community interviews; deliberative forums
student action projects with ethical guidance
assessment_practices: action research report; public product; community partner feedback
rubrics for argument quality, ethics, feasibility, reflection

learning_theories.label: Behaviorism
core_claims: learning as change in observable behavior

learning_theories.label: Cognitivism
core_claims: schema, memory limits, and strategy matter

learning_theories.label: Constructivism (incl. social constructivism)
core_claims: learners construct meaning through activity and interaction

relationships.non_determinism_rule: No 1:1 mapping is assumed; categories interact under constraints and can be combined.

influence_paths.how: sets what counts as worthwhile outcomes and legitimate knowledge
prioritizes curriculum function which drives organization (scope/sequence/integration) and evidence systems
informs plausible learning pathways and therefore feasible structures (e.g., prerequisite sequencing, practice cycles, inquiry cycles)
shapes task design, scaffolding, feedback, and cognitive/behavioral supports
policy/accountability/resources constrain or enable which hybrids can be sustained

symptoms: teachers disagree on 'what counts as success'
quick_probes: What evidence would convince us learning happened?
Which outcomes are non-negotiable and why?

symptoms: teachers adopt trendy methods but feel ineffective
students engaged but weak on foundational skills (or vice versa)
likely_root_causes: humanistic/constructivist means with essentialist ends without bridge structures
behaviorist drills used for aims requiring inquiry and agency
quick_probes: Do our daily tasks actually practice the outcomes we value?
Where is explicit instruction needed to make inquiry equitable?

symptoms: curriculum vision exists but enactment fails
quick_probes: Which constraints are structural vs negotiable?
Who has authority to change timetable, resources, assessment policy?

primary_views.label: Conceptual View (2D Map)
primary_views.purpose: Explore relationships among philosophy → conception → design, and overlay learning theories.

primary_views.label: Teacher Lens (Disagreement Diagnostic)
primary_views.purpose: Help teachers interpret classroom or PLC disagreements as conceptual misalignments.
core_interactions: see suggested conversation prompts and bridging moves

suggested_additional_views.label: Actor/Power Overlay
suggested_additional_views.idea: Show macro/meso/micro constraints and who controls what (policy, timetable, assessment).

suggested_additional_views.label: Lesson Autopsy
suggested_additional_views.idea: Upload/enter a lesson; tag practices; infer implied conception/design/evidence standard; suggest alignments.

suggested_additional_views.label: Evidence Chain Builder
suggested_additional_views.idea: Start from aims → define success evidence → derive assessment → derive learning tasks.

suggested_additional_views.label: Hybrid Recipe Studio
suggested_additional_views.idea: Choose ends (e.g., essential skills) + choose means (e.g., inquiry) and generate bridging structures (mini-lessons, practice cycles).

suggested_additional_views.label: Case Library
suggested_additional_views.idea: Browse real-ish unit cases; compare how different designs plan/instruct/assess the same topic.

references.note: Five curriculum conceptions (academic rationalism, cognitive processes, curriculum as technology, self-actualization, social reconstruction).
Humanistic curriculum design: 'meaning more important than methods', confluence of affect and cognition.
Overview tables on educational philosophies and traditional vs contemporary philosophical emphases.
Curriculum making as multi-level, socially situated practice; teacher agency ecological framing.
